data.title: Gold extends rise to another record high as uncertainty lingers over Trump policies
data.description:
Gold futures added to all-time highs Tuesday, as investors continued to seek safe-haven assets after China retaliated with tariffs on the U.S. in response to President Trump's 10% tariffs on China.

There's unease about what may happen, burnishing gold's appeal as a store of value in uncertain times, and "Trump's erratic tariff decisions are fuelling further uncertainty, which is benefiting gold as a safe haven," Commerzbank analyst Carsten Fritsch wrote.

The move keeps gold's positive momentum going after it recorded net outflows in last week's trading, according to data from J.P. Morgan, which said open interest in precious metals fell 4.6%, or $11.3B, for the week ended January 31.

The bank attributed the decline to outflows in gold contracts, but it said uncertainty around trade tariffs is pushing investors back into the safe haven asset.

The overall upward trend for gold remains intact, and any corrective pullbacks should be seen as buying opportunities since supportive factors have not fundamentally changed, XS.com's Rania Gule said, adding that as markets remain uncertain, gold likely will reamin a focus for investors both as a hedge and an investment opportunity.

Front-month Comex gold (XAUUSD:CUR) for February delivery finished +0.7% to $2,853.30/oz, another all-time settlement high, and front-month February silver (XAGUSD:CUR) closed +1.5% to $32.888/oz, its best settlement since October 30.

ETFs: (NYSEARCA:GLD), (NYSEARCA:GDX), (GDXJ), (IAU), (NUGT), (PHYS), (GLDM), (AAAU), (SGOL), (RING), (BAR), (OUNZ), (SLV), (PSLV), (SIVR), (SIL), (SILJ)

data.title: Treasury grants 'read-only' access to payments system to Musk DOGE staff
data.description:
• The Treasury Department has granted "read-only" access to members of the Elon Musk-led Department of Government Efficiency to examine "coded data" of the federal government's payment system.
  • Treasury Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs Jonathan Blum, in a Tuesday letter to Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), wrote that no requests from agencies requesting payments have been quashed by DOGE's work, Bloomberg reported.
  • Wyden had previously messaged Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent about concerns over DOGE access to the system. DOGE is seeking a review of operational efficiency within the system.
  • "Treasury is committed to safeguarding the integrity and security of the system, given the implications of any compromise or disruption to the US economy," Blum wrote.
  • Dear readers: We recognize that politics often intersects with the financial news of the day, so we invite you to click here to join the separate political discussion.

More on DOGE and Elon Musk

  • Elon Musk's DOGE gains access to Treasury Department’s payments system: NYT

  • Musk discussing blockchain use at Department of Government Efficiency

  • Musk calls USAID 'beyond repair' as he moves to shut down aid agency

  • Elon Musk doubts DOGE can achieve $2T in U.S. budget cuts under Trump

data.title: Nissan Motor likely to reject Honda offer - reports
data.description:
Nissan Motor (OTCPK:NSANY) is prepared to decline a takeover offer from Honda Motor Co. (NYSE:HMC) that would make it a subsidiary of the Japanese carmaker.

Nissan (OTCPK:NSANY) plans to hold a board meeting as soon as Wednesday afternoon, where it's expected to vote against the Honda (NYSE:HMC) offer, according to a Bloomberg report on Tuesday, which cited a person familiar with the matter. The board's final decision is still in limbo, as some senior executives support Honda (HMC) deal.

Nissan and Honda told Bloomberg that they have not made any announcements about the status of the talks, other than that the discussions are ongoing ahead of mid-February timing for a deal outline.

The Bloomberg report comes after Japan's Asahi newspaper said earlier that the two companies may abandon talks due to slow progress. Nissan ADRs fell 3% in regular trading on Tuesday, while Honda ADRs rose 2.4%.

Japanese automakers Honda Motor (HMC) and Nissan (OTCPK:NSANY) in December announced that they had entered into official talks to merge. A finished deal would create the world’s third-largest automaker by sales, behind only Toyota (TM) and Volkswagen (OTCPK:VLKAF)

data.title: Walmart trims workforce, consolidates jobs in headquarters
data.description:
Walmart (NYSE:WMT) is reportedly consolidating employees and closing its offices in North Carolina as part of a larger relocation strategy, according to a report from Fox Business.

In a memo cited by Fox, Donna Morris told employees that the retailer will be eliminating some positions and move other positions from Hoboken, New Jersey and smaller offices to its headquarters in Bentonville, Arkansas and Sunnyvale, California, as well as its new corporate location in Bellevue, Washington.

"We are making these changes to put key capabilities together, encouraging speed and shared understanding," Morris reportedly said in the memo. "Through this review process, we have eliminated some roles as we streamline how we work."

data.title: Earnings Snapshot: Mondelez expects FY25 adjusted EPS to decline 10% on costlier cocoa
RBB Bancorp outlines credit resolution timeline and anticipates loan growth in 2025
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: RBB Bancorp (NASDAQ:RBB) Q4 2024

Management View

  • David Morris, CEO, noted a decline in net income to $4.4 million or $0.25 per share, attributing the decrease primarily to credit challenges, including a $26 million construction and development (C&D) loan migrating to non-accrual status. He highlighted an improvement in net interest margin (NIM), which increased by 8 basis points due to reduced deposit costs.
  • Johnny Lee, newly appointed CEO of Royal Business Bank, emphasized the bank's continued focus on resolving non-performing loans (NPLs), the majority of which originated before 2022. He expressed confidence in resuming loan growth in upcoming quarters, supported by a healthy lending pipeline.
  • Lynn Hopkins, CFO, detailed that the provision for credit losses increased to $6 million in Q4, primarily due to specific reserves for the C&D loan and partial charge-offs on loans held for sale. She highlighted stability in non-interest income but noted a slight rise in non-interest expenses due to higher legal and professional fees.

Outlook

  • Management expects loan growth to resume in 2025, supported by a strong $200-$225 million lending pipeline. They reiterated their focus on maintaining credit quality while selectively pursuing opportunities.
  • The bank plans to potentially reintroduce a stock buyback program in 2025, while continuing to prioritize addressing credit challenges.
  • The timeline to resolve legacy credit issues has been extended to late 2025, reflecting the addition of significant NPLs in Q4.

Financial Results

  • Net income declined from $7 million in Q3 to $4.4 million in Q4, primarily due to an increase in NPLs and credit provisions.
  • The NIM improved to 2.76%, an increase of 8 basis points, driven by a decline in deposit costs.
  • Loan balances declined by $28 million due to elevated paydowns, although $126 million in loan production was achieved during the quarter. Non-interest-bearing deposits increased by $20 million.
  • Non-performing loans rose to $81 million or 2% of total assets, with the increase largely driven by the $26 million C&D loan migrating to non-accrual status.
  • Non-interest expenses were stable at $17.6 million but included higher legal and professional costs due to year-end accruals.

Q&A

  • Brendan Nosal, Hovde Group, asked about the $26 million C&D loan. CFO Lynn Hopkins explained that the project was over 50% complete and required a $4.5 million specific reserve to align with fair value.
  • Matthew Clark, Piper Sandler, inquired about the loan growth pipeline and margin outlook. CEO Johnny Lee highlighted a healthy pipeline averaging $200-$225 million and noted flexibility in pricing for high-quality credits to secure long-term relationships.
  • Kelly Motta, KBW, asked about the construction loan portfolio and credit risk mitigation. Management emphasized that legacy loans originated during COVID faced unique challenges, including material and labor shortages, and assured that proactive measures were being taken.
  • Tim Coffey, Janney, sought clarity on loan payoff mitigation strategies. Management stated they engage in early communication with borrowers and retention efforts to minimize payoffs, although elevated interest costs led some borrowers to utilize excess funds for repayments.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed concerns over the rising NPLs and credit provisions, with questions focusing on credit risk management and the timeline for resolution. Their tone was cautious but constructive.
  • Management maintained a confident tone during the prepared remarks but was more defensive in Q&A, particularly when addressing credit challenges. Key phrases, such as "we feel comfortable" and "we have a good handle," reflected efforts to reassure stakeholders.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone was slightly more cautious, reflecting the extended timeline for credit resolution and the impact of NPLs on profitability.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Net income declined from $7 million in Q3 to $4.4 million in Q4, with the drop attributed to higher credit provisions and NPLs.
  • Loan production decreased from $175 million in Q3 to $126 million in Q4, while loan balances declined compared to growth in the prior quarter.
  • The NIM improved in Q4, reversing the minimal 1 basis point increase in Q3, supported by falling deposit costs.
  • Management's tone shifted slightly, with increased emphasis on resolving credit challenges and extending the timeline for addressing legacy issues.

Risks and Concerns

  • Rising NPLs, particularly in the construction loan portfolio, pose a significant risk, with management attributing some issues to projects originated during COVID.
  • Elevated paydowns and aggressive refinancing offers from competitors continue to challenge loan growth.
  • Higher legal and professional expenses related to credit resolution efforts may persist in 2025, impacting non-interest expenses.
  • Analysts raised concerns about the bank's ability to balance credit resolution with growth initiatives.

Final Takeaway

RBB Bancorp's Q4 2024 earnings call highlighted the bank's efforts to address rising non-performing loans while maintaining a healthy lending pipeline. Management expressed confidence in resuming loan growth in 2025, supported by strong production prospects and selective credit strategies. However, challenges persist, including elevated credit provisions, declining net income, and an extended timeline for resolving legacy credit issues. Investors may closely monitor the bank's progress on mitigating credit risks and achieving its growth targets in the coming quarters.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: EA misses on Q3 bookings and guides below expectations for current quarter
data.description:
Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:EA) on Tuesday missed on core metrics for the fiscal third-quarter earnings and guided lower than expected for the current quarter. Shares of the company are up 1% in post-market trading.

Net bookings for Q3 fell 6.3% to $2.22B and were below the Wall Street expectations of $2.34B.

Operating cash flow for the quarter was down at $1.176B compared to $1.264B last year.

Of $1.883B in net revenues in Q3, full-game sales accounted for $599M, while live services and other sales amounted to $1.28B.

The company reported net income for the three months ended December 31 of $293M, compared to $290M a year ago.

For the fourth quarter, the company expects net bookings of $1.44B-$1.59B, below the expectations of $1.65B.

It sees 2025 diluted earnings per share at $3.90-$4.25 and operating cash flow of $1.8B to $1.9B, lowered from the prior range of $2.08B-$2.28B. It continues to see net bookings in the range of $7B to $7.15B; the consensus estimate is $7.15B.

The company announced plans for a $1B accelerated share repurchase, which is expected to bring total stock repurchases to $2.5B within the first year of its $5B authorization.

It also declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.19 per share, payable on March 19, 2025, to stockholders of record as of the close of business on February 26, 2025.

data.title: Columbia Sportswear issues mixed Q4 results, sets profit outlook below street view
data.description:
Shares of Columbia Sportswear Company (NASDAQ:COLM) are losing ground in Tuesday’s after-hours trading as a below-consensus Q4 profit coupled with lackluster guidance for 2025 drove shares down as much as 10%.

Sales were up 3% from a year ago to $1.096B and beat the consensus estimate of $1.08B while net income was 16% higher from a year ago to $1.80 per share but missed Wall Street’s expectations by $0.14.

“During the year we made substantial progress on our inventory reduction efforts, achieved cost savings through our Profit Improvement Program, and returned meaningful cash to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends. We also laid the foundation for Columbia’s ACCELERATE Growth Strategy, which will come to life in the seasons ahead,” CEO Tim Boyle said, adding that the company will continue to pursue cost savings to enhance profitability.

Looking ahead to 2025, Columbia’s (NASDAQ:COLM) guidance reflects its expectations as of Feb 4 and cautions that it is subject to “significant risks and business uncertainties,” namely U.S. trade policy that could adversely impact the company’s material sourcing and foreign sales. This puts anticipated earnings at $3.80 to $4.15 per share versus $3.82 in 2024 and below the consensus forecast of $4.35. This includes an anticipated 1% to 3% increase in sales.

Additionally, Columbia (NASDAQ:COLM) said it will pay a quarterly dividend of $0.30 per share on March 21 to shareholders of record as of March 10.

data.title: Brookfield Asset Management closes deal to broaden shareholder base
data.description:
Brookfield Asset Management (NYSE:BAM) and Brookfield Corp. (NYSE:BN) completed on Tuesday a previously announced arrangement that's intended to enhance BAM's corporate structure and broaden its shareholder ownership. The arrangement paves the way for the stock's inclusion in widely followed U.S. market indices, which should broaden its shareholder base and increase the liquidity of its shares.

BAM shares rose 5.1% in after-hours trading.

Through the transaction, Brookfield Asset Management (NYSE:BAM) acquired ~73% of the outstanding common shares of Brookfield's asset management business from BN in exchange for 1,194,021,145 newly issued class A limited voting shares of BAM, on a one-for-one basis. As a result, BAM has a total of 1,637,198,026 class A shares, of which BN retains an ~73% interest. Based on BAM's closing price of $58.19 on Feb. 3, 2025, the company's market capitalization stands at $95.3B.

data.title: Peter Thiel-back crypto exchange works with Jefferies on potential IPO - report
data.description:
Cryptocurrency exchange Bullish Global, whose backers include billionaire venture capitalist Peter Thiel, is weighing an initial public offering as soon as this year, according to a media report dated Tuesday.

In 2021, Bullish laid out plans to go public through a SPAC merger, but they were ultimately put on hold.

The company, led by CEO Tom Farley, is working with investment banking firm Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) on the potential debut, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg, adding that deliberations remained ongoing and the offering's details were subject to change.

Bullish boasts more than 275 staffers with offices in the U.S., Hong Kong, Singapore, Gibraltar and the Cayman Islands, its website showed.
